journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Modeling uncontrolled regeneration of diesel particulate filters, taking into account hydrocarbon slip

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Hoon Lee, Engine and Emissions Research, Center for Transportation Research, Energy Systems Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439-4815, USA. Email: hoonlee@anl.gov

abstract.p: The effect of hydrocarbon slip from a diesel oxidation catalyst on active regeneration of a diesel particulate filter is investigated by developing a generalized zero-dimensional diesel particulate filter model to predict the wall temperature of the diesel particulate filter and the trapped mass of particulate matter. Exhaust fuel injection methodology is applied to provide a high temperature for regeneration by oxidation in the diesel oxidation catalyst. However, the diesel oxidation catalyst reactions may be incomplete and hydrocarbon slip can occur. It is confirmed that two exothermic reactions, namely soot oxidation and hydrocarbon oxidation, which proceed simultaneously may result in the synergistic effect of a rise in the temperature. This is primarily because the temperature is the common factor that affects both reaction rates, i.e. a rise in the temperature caused by one reaction can affect the increase in the reaction rate of another reaction through the exotherms created. Accurate prediction of the temperature rise during active regeneration of the diesel particulate filter is dependent on several crucial factors: the initial wall temperature of the diesel particulate filter, the inlet temperature of the diesel particulate filter, the initial loading level of particulate matter, the exhaust mass flow rate, the oxygen concentration, and hydrocarbon slip. Several simulations revealed that hydrocarbon slip can be one of the reasons for uncontrolled regeneration of the diesel particulate filter. It is concluded that, if there is a considerable amount of hydrocarbon slip, then uncontrolled regeneration of the diesel particulate filter easily occurs when the exhaust mass flow rate is rapidly reduced to the idle condition during regeneration. Flow transient simulations also confirmed that the temperature ramp-up rate and the point of time when the exhaust mass flow rate is reduced determine the overall trend of the temperature rise and the characteristics of the thermal behavior of the diesel particulate filter.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, significant effort has been put into studying the oxidation in a diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) and regeneration of the diesel particulate filter (DPF) continuously, through either experiments or simulations. However, less attention has been paid to understanding the effect of hydrocarbon (HC) slip on the active DPF regeneration process, which is believed to generate a high-temperature spike inside the DPF. It may cause uncontrolled (or runaway) regeneration of the DPF and, as a result, device failures through abnormal thermal stress.1

HC emissions result when fuel molecules do not burn or burn only partially. However, diesel engine-out HCs are oxidized in the DOC; consequently, the HC emission level is low in most operating conditions. Thus, previous studies have primarily focused on the DOC for reducing these HC species, suggesting some alternatives by means of optimizing the catalyst geometry and the coating level of platinum group metals (PGMs),2 or applying turbulent metal foil design to the DOC substrate.3

However, the difficulty occurs when additional fuel is added to the exhaust gas upstream of the DOC. This is done to raise the exhaust gas temperature through additional exothermic oxidation in the DOC. In some situations, some HC species in the fuel escape from oxidation slip through the DOC owing to the high exhaust mass flow rate or high exhaust fuel injection (EFI) rate.1,2,4,5 In other words, HC slip, which is the main theme of this paper, is the secondary unburned HC emissions in the exhaust gas downstream of the DOC. HC species downstream of the DPF may also be called HC slip and have been studied, especially for the aftertreatment system which includes a selective catalytic reduction device.6 In this study, however, the HC slip is modeled with an assumption that it originated only from the EFI which is the main cause of the HC slip that directly supplies raw fuel in the exhaust stream through an extra fuel injector (which is also called a fuel vaporizer or HC doser). Besides the HC slip, the EFI system has its own shortcomings such as the high cost of and the necessity for additional equipment. However, the EFI system is widely used, especially for heavy-duty diesel applications, since it is possible to prevent engine wear by avoiding oil dilution, which is one of the crucial problems of the in-cylinder late post-injection method.7

Unlike the actual cause, the substantial effect of HC slip on the aftertreatment system performance, including the rise in the DPF wall temperature is still uncertain. Previous experimental research studies2,8 have reported that HC slip may lead to uncontrolled regeneration of the DPF. On the other hand, Harris et al.9 suggested that HC slip can be beneficial to the DPF regeneration process since the additional exotherms created from HC oxidation can significantly enhance the soot oxidation reaction. This implies the possible advantage of controlling the HC slip, which can increase the completeness of the DPF regeneration process.

Device survivability and durability of DPF are challenged by several key factors including the excessive thermal stress due to DPF uncontrolled regeneration. DPF uncontrolled regeneration can occur in the worst engine operating conditions, such as when the engine goes back to the idle condition after high-temperature operation with the DPF heavily loaded with particulate matter (PM).10–12 In this situation, the wall temperature inside the DPF can rise to 1000 °C or higher locally, and this is regarded as the most critical origin of DPF substrate and washcoat failure.13,14 In particular, based on intensive experiments, Zhan et al.15,16 specifically defined all the DPF uncontrolled regeneration phenomena and categorized them into three different types with main causes and possible alternatives for each of those to ensure controlled regeneration.

In particular, to control the amount of HC slip and its thermochemical effect on DPF active regeneration, the control logic of improving the fuel dosing17 and the pulsed EFI concept18 were introduced. Particularly, pulsed EFI methodology was intensively studied as a possible solution for preventing DPF uncontrolled regeneration.1 Research into related issues, such as the effect of HC adsorbed on soot particles on DPF regeneration19 and the relationship between the HC concentration and the DPF regeneration characteristics, was also carried out.20

sec.title: Model descriptions
sec.p: A zero-dimensional (0D) DPF model is developed and is implemented in MATLAB R2010a. An ordinary differential equation (ODE) solver ‘ode15s’ which is designed for stiff-type problems is used to solve the mass and energy equations with source terms that release exothermic heat energy from the chemical reactions.

The primary objective of the model is to carry out the transient thermal response simulation of the DPF by capturing the wall temperature traces during the DPF active regeneration process involving HC slip. Two simultaneously occurring oxidation reactions for both solid-phase (PM) and gas-phase (HC) species are considered.

sec.title: Assumptions
sec.p: The five assumptions that were made during the development of the 0D DPF model based on 0D global single-step chemical kinetics to keep the computational complexity to a minimum are as follows.

list-item.p: The only significant heat source is the exothermic oxidation reactions of both soot and HCs.
The exhaust gas is an ideal gas (air), is laminar, and has incompressible flow.
The DPF wall temperature and species concentrations inside the DPF are assumed to be uniform and are equal to the values and concentrations at the DPF outlet.
The reaction rate constants and the other parameters used are of the Arrhenius form.

The kinetic and potential energies, ash accumulation, deposition of incoming soot, reverse reactions in the oxidation processes, catalytic PM oxidation, heat transfer across the boundary of the control volume, and the mass diffusion effect are neglected.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: The governing equations of the 0D DPF model developed from fundamental conservation principles and linked to chemical kinetics are a system of ODEs. Thus, both the reaction rate and the production rate depend on only the species concentration of reactants and the process temperature where the temperature changes with time. To solve the governing equations of the system, one-step global kinetics with three species (fuel, reactants, and products) and simplified thermochemistry are employed. The initial and boundary conditions are used as first iterates to solve the energy and mass balance equations. The control volume defined by the dashed line in Figure 1 includes the fluid, the soot inside the DPF, and the DPF wall material.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the 0D DPF model.

sec.p:
The chemical kinetics of single-step forward one-way global reactions of soot and HC oxidation mechanisms are described to clarify that the energy balance and mass balance equations are coupled through

sec.title: Propane (C3H8) oxidation
sec.p: The HC oxidation mechanism used in the 0D DPF model is an empirical global model that captures the overall behavior in a sequence of global steps. Global models do not capture the details of HC oxidation; however, they can be useful for engineering approximations if their limitations are considered. The single-step expression suggested for the approximation for global reaction is21

In reality, different ranges of HC concentration are present in the exhaust gas mixture and these ranges may vary depending on the diesel combustion mode. However, considering the complications in modeling HC reactions in the ranges present in a typical diesel exhaust, a relatively lower molecular weight of the HC family, such as propane (C3H8) or propylene (C3H6), is often used as representative.19,26,27 Although this will somewhat sacrifice the fidelity of the model, it greatly simplifies the kinetics capturing the general effect on the system.28,29 In this paper, therefore, all HCs were lumped into a C3H8 value, and the Arrhenius form of the reaction rate used is

sec.p: The most common assumption adopted in the combustion literature for the concentration exponents is that the rate expression is first order in both fuel and oxidizer. Therefore, the reaction orders m and n in equation (30) can be 1.0, as long as it is applied to problems for which the air-to-fuel ratio does not vary with time or position.29

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: The 0D DPF model used in this study is validated1 by comparison with the integrated system-level model (ISM) which has been previously developed and continuously validated18,30–34 by several researchers. The ISM integrates the one-dimensional (1D) DOC model and 1D DPF model together with the engine model, emissions models, and advanced controller model. To compare the performance and the ability to predict the DPF wall temperature during DPF regeneration of both models directly under the same input condition, the 0D DPF model first is converted to the Simulink platform by using the level-2 M-file S function and then is integrated into the ISM. Figure 2 shows fairly good agreement between the two simulation results. The temperature ramp-up rate during the temperature ramp-up range (both are defined later in equation (38) and equation (39) respectively) is higher in the 0D DPF model results. This is due to the effect of the thermal inertia considered in the 1D DPF model. The difference between the DPF peak wall temperatures is relatively large in the higher-inlet-temperature case, where the 0D DPF model underpredicts the temperature levels in the filter. This is primarily due to the simplified assumptions made in the 0D DPF model. Thus, the deviation can be minimized by modifying the 0D DPF model assumptions considering the heat transfer, catalytic soot oxidation, pressure drop, and nitrogen-dioxide-assisted (passive) regeneration, which are neglected in this study for computational efficiency and simplicity.

caption.p:
Model comparison with respect to the DPF wall temperature (Tinit,DPF = 200 °C; PM loading, 5.65 g/l;
m
·

0.05 kg/s;
x

= 0.115).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; 1D: one-dimensional; 0D: zero-dimensional.

sec.p: To validate the effect of HC slip on DPF regeneration, the 0D model results are compared with published reference data owing to the lack of experimental data. As will be seen later, the DPF peak wall temperature increment due to the HC slip effect varies depending on several other input conditions but is typically in the range up to 30 °C in moderate conditions. This value is found to be similar to that of the experimental data reported at 20–25 °C as a contribution of HC slip to the rise in the DPF wall temperature during DPF active regeneration.9

In fact, very few technical reports and papers which are available contain studies of HC oxidation inside the DPF during regeneration and its effect on the regeneration process. Instead, most research has focused on the adsorbed HC species on soot particle or the so-called soluble organic fraction (SOF). The SOF is relatively easy to oxidize below 400 °C and so has only a weak effect on DPF active regeneration which occurs in the temperature range of 500 °C or higher. However, the HC species coming directly from EFI, and not from in-cylinder combustion, are considered as highly flammable and combustible substances, and so they may affect the dynamics of soot oxidation during DPF active regeneration.

sec.title: Steady flow conditions
sec.p: To investigate the potential effect of HC slip on DPF regeneration, the oxidation reactions of both soot and HCs are simulated simultaneously using the 0D DPF model. Simulation duration is extended to 6000 s to see the temperature traces broadly and HC slip is set to 1000 ppm at the initial point and to 0 ppm at the half-point (3000 s) of duration to represent the end of the EFI and the completion of the regeneration processes respectively.

Figure 3 shows the DPF wall temperature as a function of time for three scenarios. It clearly illustrates the effect of HC slip which possibly leads to a higher peak temperature on the DPF wall during the early stage of the DPF active regeneration processes. It is obvious that the DPF wall temperature increment (indicated by arrows) in the ‘soot+HC (1000 ppm)’ case is approximately 30% higher than the summation of increments in each of the oxidation reactions, namely the ‘soot only’ case and the ‘HC (1000 ppm) only’ case.

caption.p:
(a) DPF wall temperature and (a) trapped soot mass during DPF active regeneration (Ti,DPF = 700 °C; HC slip, 1000 ppm; PM loading, 5.5 g/l;
m
·
= 0.05 kg/s;
x
O
2
= 0.12).
HC: hydrocarbon; DPF: diesel particulate filter; EFI: exhaust fuel injection.

sec.p: That effect is supported by additional simulation studies which demonstrate the DPF peak wall temperature during the first 100 s of the regeneration process. The results are shown in Figure 4 and Figure 5. In particular, Figure 4 corresponds to the HC slip of the 2000 ppm case in Figure 5.

caption.p: DPF peak wall temperature with respect to (a) the PM loading level and (b) the mass flow rate (Ti,DPF = 800 °C; HC slip, 2000 ppm).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; PM: particulate matter.

Tp,w,DPF versus three main factors, namely the PM loading level, the mass flow rate, and the O2 concentration, with respect to different amounts of HC slip (Ti,DPF = 800 °C;
x
O
2
= 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20).
HC: hydrocarbon; DPF: diesel particulate filter; PM: particulate matter.

sec.p: In Figure 5, each plot is depicted with a different amount of HC slip while each layer represents different exhaust O2 concentrations (5%, 10%, 15%, and 20% from the bottom respectively). The conclusion drawn here is that the DPF can easily experience uncontrolled regeneration with a critically high temperature (greater than 1000 °C) which may cause thermal stress on the DPF wall and substrate at lower exhaust mass flow rates, higher O2 concentrations, and higher PM loading levels. The DPF peak temperature is also proportional to the amount of HC slip but is limited at high exhaust mass flow rates.

In order to examine the contribution of the HC slip to the rise in the DPF wall temperature, parametric case studies are performed. Figure 6 and Figure 7, which represent the high-flow-rate case and the low-flow-rate case respectively, demonstrate the results with a high DPF inlet temperature of 700 °C, a fixed initial PM loading level of 5.0 g/l, and a fixed exhaust O2 concentration of 0.12. sec.p: It is obvious that the phenomenon of the uncontrolled temperature rise occurring during DPF regeneration is not just a summation effect but is a synergistic effect which is definitely caused by a combination of two coupled exothermic oxidation reactions. This effect is closely related to the reaction rate and kinetic parameters of each reaction and mostly depends on the value of the DPF inlet temperature and the exhaust mass flow rate.
To describe the DPF inlet temperature contribution, the temperature increment rate Tinc is also defined as

where
Δ
T
s , HC
represents the absolute temperature increment of the soot+HC slip case. The results are plotted in Figure 8 to Figure 11. HC slip is fixed at 2000 ppm in Figure 8 and Figure 9, while the PM loading level is fixed at 5.0 g/l in Figure 10 and Figure 11. The exhaust O2 mole fraction is fixed at 0.12 for all cases. As seen, the synergistic effect of the temperature rise is enhanced as the DPF inlet temperature increases. In particular, in the case of the highest DPF inlet temperature of 700 °C with the highest HC slip of 3000 ppm and the lowest exhaust mass flow rate of 0.01 kg/s depicted in Figure 11, Tinc reached 160%. It is considerably reduced to 7.2% at the higher exhaust mass flow rate depicted in Figure 10.

sec.title: ‘Back-to-idle’ effect
sec.p: Often the engine operating condition is not in a steady state but is in a continuously changing condition. In particular, low-speed driving cycles, such as those in a city, are known to be critical for vehicles equipped with a DPF. This is because the low exhaust mass flow rate in idle-like engine operation conditions results in a very low convective heat transfer rate, which causes a rapid increase in the DPF bed temperature. Considering all the key factors, one of the alternative plans that can compensate for the negative effect of the lower exhaust mass flow rate will be a decrease in the exhaust O2 concentration. However, the main problem is that most of the possible methods that would lead to a lower exhaust O2 content, such as increasing the exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) rate or decreasing the amount of intake air, also decrease the exhaust mass flow rate at the same time. In particular, this kind of situation is defined as the main cause of uncontrolled regeneration.15

In order to model the ‘unexpected’ and ‘undesirable’ engine idle-like conditions during DPF regeneration, several transient simulations are performed. The exhaust mass flow rate is reduced from 0.05 kg/s to 0.01 kg/s and the exhaust O2 mole concentration is increased from 0.06 to 0.20 simultaneously at a certain point of the regeneration period while a sufficiently high level of the DPF inlet temperature is given. The results depicted in Figure 12 and Figure 13 are interesting. It is confirmed that, if there is no HC slip, then the DPF wall temperature increment is below 50 °C even with a rapid reduction in the exhaust mass flow rate together with a rapid increase in the exhaust O2 concentration at the very early timing of the regeneration. In contrast, when a considerable amount of HC slip occurs, the increment in the temperature can exceed beyond 600 °C so that the peak temperature may reach as high as 1400 °C. The reason why the mass flow reduction timing affects the temperature increment is that, the earlier the mass flow rate is reduced, the higher is the amount of soot still remaining inside the DPF at that time.

caption.p:
Effect of mass flow reduction on (a) Tw,DPF and (b) the trapped soot mass without HC slip (PM loading, 5.75 g/l; Ti,DPF = 800 °C;
m
·
= 0.05→0.01 kg/s;
x
O
2
= 0.06→0.20).
DPF: diesel particulate filter.

Effect of rapid mass flow reduction on (a) Tw,DPF and (b) the trapped soot mass with HC slip of 2000 ppm (PM loading, 5.75 g/l; Ti,DPF = 800 °C;
m
·
= 0.05→0.01 kg/s;
x
O
2
= 0.06→0.20).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; HC: hydrocarbon.

sec.p: This can be regarded as another synergistic effect, which is created by both HC oxidation and exhaust mass flow reduction. This emphasizes again that careful consideration regarding the temperature rise effect of the HC slip must be taken into account for the development of safe DPF regeneration strategies and the design of reliable diesel aftertreatment devices.

sec.title: Critical point of flow reduction
sec.p: It is shown in Figure 12 and Figure 13 that, the earlier the mass flow rate reduction point, the higher is the DPF peak wall temperature where the trapped soot mass remaining at the reduction time is identified as a main reason. However, it is applicable only under conditions of sufficiently high DPF inlet temperature, where soot is easily oxidized. In other words, below a certain level of the DPF inlet temperature, the earlier exhaust mass flow rate reduction timing may result in a lower DPF peak wall temperature since the soot oxidation reaction might not be activated sufficiently well to generate considerable exotherms. The other problem in the exhaust mass flow rate transient simulation is that it is not possible to predict the timing of mass flow reduction since it may occur at any time during vehicle operation, i.e. the DPF wall temperature at the exhaust mass flow reduction point may also affect the overall trend of the rise in the temperature and the DPF thermal behavior as another key factor. Figure 14 shows this trend clearly.

caption.p:
Effect of the mass flow reduction point on Tp,w,DPF (PM loading, 5.0 g/l; Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C;
m
·
= 0.05→0.01 kg/s;
x
O
2
= 0.03→0.10; HC slip, 0→2000 ppm).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; EFI: exhaust fuel injection.

sec.p: As seen, it is possible to assume that there is a certain point of time dividing the DPF peak wall temperature characteristics as a boundary. It is defined as a critical point tcrit in this study. This means that, if the exhaust mass flow rate is reduced exactly at tcrit during regeneration, the DPF peak wall temperature has its maximum value. Accordingly, the EFI duration can be divided into two regions, namely the pre-tcrit region and the post-tcrit region, as shown in Figure 14. If the exhaust mass flow rate reduction occurs at some point of time in the pre-tcrit region, then, the later the point, the higher is the DPF peak wall temperature (indicated by arrow 1) which means that the temperature rise depends more on the DPF wall temperature at that time. On the other hand, if flow reduction occurs at some point of time in the post-tcrit region, the results are the opposite (indicated by arrow 2) which means that the temperature rise is dependent more on the mass of soot remaining inside the DPF at that time. Therefore, in order to investigate the effect of the exhaust mass flow rate transient on DPF active regeneration, tcrit should be identified first for each regeneration condition and taken into account.

Additional simulations are performed by varying the initial exhaust mass flow rate from 0.05 kg/s to 0.10 kg/s to see its effect on the DPF peak wall temperature trend and the value in the so-called ‘drop-back-to-idle’ condition. The exhaust mass flow rate reduction points are also varied within the 400 s of the EFI duration; then tcrit is found for each case based on the timing of the occurrence of the maximum DPF peak temperature. Table 5 shows the results.

caption.p:
Critical point and DPF peak wall temperature with respect to the initial mass flow rate (Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C; PM loading, 5.0 g/l;
x
O
2
= 0.03→0.10; HC slip, 0→2000 ppm).

tr.td: Tp,w,DPF (°C) when the mass flow rate and the O2 concentration are changed at tcrit

sec.p: Figure 15 shows the trends specifically that the exhaust mass flow rate sweep affects the phasing of the DPF peak wall temperature. Arrows 1 and 2 again represent the characteristics which are previously illustrated in Figure 14. In addition to these, it is seen that the DPF peak wall temperature trends for the values of the initial exhaust mass flow rate in the pre-tcrit region and the post-tcrit region (indicated by arrows 3 and 4) are opposite to each other. Furthermore, it is also important to note that the maximum DPF peak wall temperature at tcrit increases as the initial exhaust mass flow rate increases (indicated by arrow 5) since this emphasizes the potential danger of a higher initial exhaust mass flow rate, which is considered relatively safer than a low initial exhaust mass flow rate. A primary cause of this is related to the temperature ramp-up range and temperature ramp-up rate which are defined as

caption.p:
Effect of the initial mass flow rate on the timing and trends of the Tp,w,DPF occurrence (PM loading, 5.0 g/l; Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C;
m
·
= 0.05→0.01 kg/s;
x
O
2
= 0.03→0.10; HC slip, 0→2000 ppm).
DPF: diesel particulate filter.

sec.p: One more feature that should be considered from the results is that, the higher exhaust mass flow rate, the sooner the tcrit value is obtained for the DPF peak wall temperature (indicated by arrow 6). This means that the DPF wall temperature not only drops rapidly after EFI but also increases rapidly at the initial stage of regeneration for higher exhaust mass flow rates, as shown in Figure 16.

caption.p:
Effect of the mass flow rate on the temperature ramp-up rate and the DPF peak wall temperature (Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C; PM loading, 5.0 g/l;
x
O
2
= 0.12).
DPF: diesel particulate filter.

sec.title: HC slip contribution
sec.p: In Figure 17, the general relationships between the temperature ramp-up rate, the DPF peak wall temperature, and HC slip are illustrated with respect to the exhaust mass flow rate. In this case, the exhaust mass flow rate is set to be constant without reduction for all cases. As seen, the temperature ramp-up rate is not affected by HC slip, whereas the DPF peak temperature is increased by HC slip. Also, the DPF peak temperature decreases as the exhaust mass flow rate increases.

caption.p:
Effects of HC slip and the mass flow rate on the temperature ramp-up rate and the DPF peak wall temperature (Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C; PM loading, 5.0 g/l;
x
O
2
= 0.12).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; HC: hydrocarbon.

sec.p: With this, the trends in the DPF peak wall temperature considering the effect of HC slip and the rapid reduction in the exhaust mass flow rate are further investigated. First, the tcrit value for each case is calculated as shown in Table 6.

caption.p:
Critical point and DPF peak wall temperature with respect to the mass flow rate (Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C; PM loading, 5.0 g/l;
x
O
2
= 0.12→0.17; HC slip, 0→2000 ppm).

tr.td: Tp,w,DPF (°C) when the mass flow rate and the O2 concentration are changed at tcrit

sec.p: Then, Figure 18 illustrates the effect of HC slip on the DPF peak wall temperature when the exhaust mass flow rate is rapidly reduced to an idle-like condition at some point in the post-tcrit region, in the pre-tcrit region, and exactly at tcrit. These correspond to cases (a), (b), and (c) respectively in the figure. It is obvious that excess HC slip can result in a high-temperature spike inside the DPF which may cause device failure. Specifically, the HC slip effect is considerable when the vehicle speed is decreased from a higher speed to an engine idle-like condition at the critical point (case (c)).

caption.p:
Effects of HC slip and the mass flow rate on the DPF peak wall temperature when the mass flow rate is reduced to 0.01 kg/s at (a) 400 s (post-tcrit region), (b) 120 s (pre-tcrit region), (c) the critical point (Tinit,DPF = 400 °C; Ti,DPF = 400→700 °C; PM loading, 5.0 g/l;
x
O
2
= 0.12→0.17; HC slip, 0→2000 ppm).
DPF: diesel particulate filter; HC: hydrocarbon.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study utilizes a modeling approach to aftertreatment device safety and durability maximization in order to try to analyze DPF uncontrolled regeneration, by investigating the effect of HC slip. This work reported the potential problems and effects of HC slip on DPF active regeneration under the EFI condition. Global oxidation kinetics were implemented for the oxidation reaction of both soot and HCs and applied to the 0D DPF model, which was developed and used in this work over wide ranges of species concentrations (HC, soot, and O2) and exhaust mass flow rate, in a reasonable temperature domain.

The 0D DPF model results are validated with published data and show typical and general DPF regeneration performances and thermal behaviors under various conditions fairly well. From the simulation results, it is confirmed that two exothermic oxidation reactions, namely soot and HC, with simultaneous processes may result in the synergistic effect of a temperature rise inside the DPF during regeneration.

The HC slip level is determined by the exhaust mass flow rate, the EFI rate, and the DOC configuration. It affects DPF regeneration together with several other factors, namely the DPF inlet temperature, the exhaust mass flow rate, the exhaust O2 concentration, the temperature ramp-up rate, and the initial PM loading level.

If the exhaust mass flow rate is steady during regeneration, then, the lower the flow rate, the higher is the DPF peak wall temperature owing to the lower convective heat transfer rate. For the flow transient condition, it is confirmed that a dramatic reduction in the exhaust mass flow rate under the excess HC slip condition can cause a significant temperature rise effect on the DPF, resulting in DPF uncontrolled regeneration and device failure. However, it should be noted that the higher exhaust mass flow rate causes a higher temperature ramp-up rate at the initial stage of the regeneration process which can also cause DPF uncontrolled regeneration. Specifically, if the exhaust mass flow rate is dropped to the idle-like condition in the pre-tcrit region during regeneration, the higher initial exhaust mass flow rate advances the timing of the occurrence of the DPF peak temperature and results in a higher DPF peak temperature.

The model results of the excess HC slip case shows an increase in the DPF peak wall temperature during regeneration under both steady and transient operating conditions. Under all circumstances, the mutual interactions of several key factors during operation affect the evolution of DPF uncontrolled regeneration, as shown in Figure 19.

caption.p: Key factors that affect DPF uncontrolled regeneration.

RPM: r/min; EGR: exhaust gas recirculation; DOC: diesel oxidation catalyst; HC: hydrocarbon; EFI: exhaust fuel injection; DPF: diesel particulate filter; PM: particulate matter; NO2: nitrogen dioxide; PGM: platinum group metal.

sec.p: Based on the results in this paper and the previous study,1 two major types of DPF uncontrolled regeneration previously identified by Zhan et al.15 are modified and recategorized in Table 7.

caption.p: Modified DPF uncontrolled regeneration patterns.

tr.td: Excess exotherm at the start of regeneration with a high-temperature ramp-up rate

list-item.p: 1. Close-coupled DOC to reduce the SOF content in the DPF

tr.td: Temperature spike caused by dramatic exhaust flow reduction (back-to-idle condition)

The combination of the following:
1. Excess PM loading
2. High exhaust O2 concentration
3. Low convective heat transfer
4. Excess HC slip
5. Critical point of flow reduction

fn.p: PM: particulate matter; DOC: diesel oxidation catalyst; SOF: soluble organic fraction; DPF: diesel particulate filter; HC: hydrocarbon; EGR: exhaust gas recirculation.
